awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH:  From Metabolites to Continent: Host-parasite Interaction across Spatio-temporal Scales
awd_abstract_narration:
All living organisms interact with parasites. Often, the outcome of these interactions is either morbidity or the death of the host. However, in some instances, the behavior of the host can be manipulated by the parasite. This behavioral manipulation increases the transmission of the parasite, either to a new environment crucial for its development, or to a new host. Although many examples of parasitic behavioral manipulation exist, little is known of the mechanisms underlying it. Investigators will study the genetic basis of parasitic manipulation by analyzing the gene expression of host brains at the exact moment they are being manipulated. Because the parasite that manipulates the behavior also results in host sickness, the investigators will use a non-manipulative parasite as a comparison. Thus, they will be able to distinguish between the genetic basis of sickness and manipulation. Since many manipulators exploit immune systems and neural connections, understanding how they manipulate their host has practical and theoretical applications, leading us to better understand sickness behavior and mental disorders. Brain snatchers are very popular among the general public, including K-12, as they turn their host into "zombies." Investigators will leverage this popularity to bring science to K-12 classrooms and local communities. 

Investigators will study the proximate mechanisms of parasitic behavioral manipulation, by studying gene expression of the host during the moment of behavioral manipulation. Because the manipulative parasite also causes sickness, and the manipulation is immediately followed by death, a generalist non-manipulative parasite that also results in sickness and death of the host will be used as control. Healthy, uninfected, host brains will be used as a baseline for normal gene expression. Investigators will use Illumina HiSeq 2500 technology to compare the transcriptome of manipulated host brains with those that present general sickness and death symptoms. This will allow the research team to capture the genes that are differentially expressed during manipulation and are not related to general sickness or death processes. Understanding the gene expression of a manipulated host is a fundamental step to understand the mechanisms underlying behavioral manipulation by parasites. Additionally, the data will be interpreted in an interdisciplinary broader context, together with other approaches (different ecological scales) employed by the same research group to fully understand the parasitic manipulation. Results of this project will be published in peer-reviewed journals and also presented at conferences. All data from this project will be hosted on public databases such as Genbank and Dryad as well as stored on Penn State's publically accessible databases.

por.por_cntn:
Host-parasite interactions are shaped by the evolutionary arms race between both parties.  In this project we explored how the the parasitic fungus O. unilateralis s.l. controls ant host behavior alters the expression of other host’s genes beyond those related to general sickness. To assess the transcriptional changes in the heads of ants during the end point of parasitic infection (i.e. before death), we examined the differences in gene expression level using the healthy ants as baseline (n=6). Moribund ants infected by B. bassiana (n=6) had a total of 1,755 genes differently expressed, from which 780 (44%) and 975 (56%) were down and up regulated, respectively, related to the base line gene expression in healthy ants. At the moment of the manipulation, the ants infected with O. unilateralis (n=6) had 1,292 genes with altered levels related to the baseline gene expression in healthy ants, with 713 (55%) and 579 (45%) under and over expressed, respectively. 

Manipulated ants had the total of 1,292 differentially expressed genes related to healthy ants. From those, 504 were similarly altered in moribund ants. It means that the manipulated ants had 788 genes uniquely altered at the moment of the manipulation related to both healthy and moribund ants. Thus, even though we reduced our list of genes by removing those that overlapped between moribund and manipulated ants, we still have hundreds of genes that could be associated to the manipulation event.  It is also possible, however, that these genes could be associated with an aspect of pathology or sickness not observed in ants infected by B. bassiana.  With this large number of genes with altered expression levels, it is not possible to point to specific candidates free of bias. We suggest it is only possible to tentatively speculate on the possible roles played by some of these genes and emphasize there are many genes and possible pathways that we were not able to consider. 

We found alterations in the expression of genes associated with neurotransmission. In the head of the manipulated ant, we found that the sodium- and chloride-dependent γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) transporter 1 (GAT1) homolog was up-regulated. This high-affinity membrane protein rapidly removes GABA from synaptic signaling. The increased expression of this gene may result in shorter duration of the synaptic signaling. Along the same line the octopamine transporter was also up-regulated on the head of the manipulated ants. Additionally, we found that a Catecholamines up (Catsup) homolog was down regulated in manipulated ants. This gene codes for the membrane protein catsup which, in Drosophila melanogaster, is a key regulator of dopamine (DA) synthesis. 

The -omics approaches are promising tools to unravel the molecular basis of manipulation by parasites. Gene expression is valuable to point directions and formulate new hypotheses for further investigation. However, it generates long lists of candidate genes, with or without predicted annotation that are difficult to interpret. It is often the case that researchers will make the entire list available, but choose only few genes to discuss. This open up the possibility of an equivocal interpretation that could lead future projects in the wrong direction. In this study we approached the mechanisms of behavioral manipulation in a new manner. The use of general sickness response helped us to narrow down the potential list of genes associated with host responses that could be involved in parasite manipulation of behavior. More importantly, it demonstrates how the lack of this type of control is likely leading the research for general mechanisms of proximate mechanisms of behavioral control in the wrong direction. Obviously, there is no such thing as a perfect control, but we argue our work may be a step in the right direction.

Additionally, the manipulation of ants by the O. unilateralis is likely to be a multistep process, with the gradual transformation of a normal ant into a puppet controlled by the parasite. Here, and in all the studies involving behavioral manipulation by parasite, we only address the moment where the manipulation has taken place. It might be the case that the key to understanding the molecular basis of behavioral manipulation is, in fact, at the moments preceding the manipulation. Thus, it would be of great interest to study the gradual changes on the host molecular network that make a normal individual to become a vehicle driven by a parasite.
